metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 4 of 2008 in representative capacity against State of Jammu & Kashmir for declaration that Jammu & Kashmir Big Landed Property Abolition Act, XVII of 2007 (the Act) is void, inoperative and ultra vires of Yuvaraj Karan Singh, and for declaration of entitlement to retain peaceful possession of lands.
Maghar Singh filed Civil Suit No. 59 of 2007 challenging validity of the Act; Mr. Justice Kilam rejected contentions and held Act valid.
Appellant's suit before District Court conceded points against Act's validity decided by Mr. Justice Kilam; District Judge bound by that decision, dismissed suit holding Act valid.
Appellant preferred Civil Appeal No. 4 of 2009 to High Court of Jammu & Kashmir; Maghar Singh's appeal No. 29 of 2008 heard together; Division Bench held Act valid, dismissed both appeals.
High Court dismissed application for leave to appeal to Supreme Court; special leave granted.

Maharaja Hari Singh succeeded in 1925; public agitation led to Regulation 1 of 1934 associating subjects in legislation and administration, but s.3 preserved all inherent legislative, executive, judicial powers of Maharaja.
Jammu & Kashmir Constitution Act 14 of 1939 promulgated; ss.4 and 5 preserved Maharaja's powers; other provisions subject to overriding powers of Maharaja.
Indian Independence Act, 1947 lapsed suzerainty; States free subject to proviso.

Tribal raiders invaded on October 22, 1947; Maharaja signed Instrument of Accession to India on October 25, 1947, acceding on defence, external affairs, communications; cl.8 preserved Maharaja's sovereignty.
Maharaja's proclamation March 5, 1948 set up popular interim government headed by Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah; functioned under 1939 Constitution.
Maharaja's proclamation June 20, 1949 entrusted all powers (legislative, executive, judicial) to Yuvaraj Karan Singh during absence for health reasons.
Yuvaraj Karan Singh's proclamation November 25, 1949 applied Constitution of India insofar as applicable to State.
Constitution of India came into force January 26, 1950; Constitution (Application to J&K) Order, 1950 (C.O. 10) issued.
Revenue Minister's policy statement August 13, 1950: transfer proprietorship to tiller, limit to 20 acres plus allowances.

Yuvaraj promulgated Act on October 17, 1950 under powers from 1939 Constitution Act and Maharaja's June 20, 1949 proclamation; abolishes big landed estates, transfers to tillers; s.4 extinguishes proprietors' rights except specified lands; s.26 provides annuity till Constituent Assembly decides compensation.
Yuvaraj's proclamation April 20, 1951 for Constituent Assembly on adult franchise to frame Constitution.
Constituent Assembly framed Constitution abolishing hereditary rule; Yuvaraj elected Sadar-i-Riyasat November 13, 1952.
Constituent Assembly decided no compensation to proprietors.

legal_issues.text: Whether Yuvaraj Karan Singh had authority to promulgate the Jammu & Kashmir Big Landed Property Abolition Act, XVII of 2007.
Whether the Act is invalid for lack of compensation.
Whether the Act is invalid under Art. 254 due to inconsistency with earlier Acts No. 10 of 1990 and No. 4 of 1977.
Whether Constituent Assembly was properly constituted to decide on compensation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Maharaja Hari Singh was constitutional monarch post-1934 Regulation and 1939 Act, could not convey higher powers to Yuvaraj.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Regulation 1 of 1934 s.3; Constitution Act 14 of 1939 ss.4,5

petitioner_arguments.text: Instrument of Accession, March 5, 1948 proclamation, November 25, 1949 proclamation, and Art.370 made Maharaja/Yuvaraj constitutional monarch without plenary legislative powers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Instrument of Accession cl.8; Constitution of India Art.370

petitioner_arguments.text: Act invalid for no compensation; Constituent Assembly improperly constituted.
Act repugnant to earlier Acts under Art.254.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.254; earlier Acts 10 of 1990, 4 of 1977

court_reasoning.text: Maharaja was absolute monarch; 1934 Regulation s.3 and 1939 Act ss.4,5 preserved all inherent powers; Independence Act freed from paramountcy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Maharaja retained absolute powers despite constitutions.

court_reasoning.text: Instrument of Accession preserved sovereignty; March 5, 1948 proclamation did not surrender powers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cabinet functioned under Maharaja's overriding powers.

court_reasoning.text: June 20, 1949 proclamation validly delegated all powers to Yuvaraj as absolute monarch could do so.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Like sovereign legislature delegating powers (citing Delhi Laws Act).

court_reasoning.text: November 25, 1949 proclamation and Art.370 did not limit Yuvaraj's internal legislative powers; Art.370 temporary for Union-State relations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plenary powers for State governance unaffected.

court_reasoning.text: s.26 provides for compensation; no Art.31 limit then applicable; Constituent Assembly validly constituted by Yuvaraj.
Art.254 inapplicable as Concurrent List not extended to State; no State Legislature in constitutional sense.

holdings.text: Yuvaraj Karan Singh competent to enact the Act; Act valid.
Act provides for compensation via s.26; no invalidity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney-General v. De Keyser's Royal Hotel Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Prerogative rights as residue of discretionary authority.
Sovereign can delegate all powers without limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Jammu & Kashmir Big Landed Property Abolition Act, XVII of 2007
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act extinguishing proprietors' rights, providing annuity; held valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.370 temporary provisions did not limit Ruler's internal powers; others applied with modifications but not affecting validity.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Application to J&K) Order, 1950 (C.O.10)
statutes_cited.relevance: Limited Parliament's powers; applied specified Articles.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld High Court and lower courts; held Jammu & Kashmir Big Landed Property Abolition Act valid and intra vires; appellant not entitled to declarations sought.

key_quotes.text: "all powers legislative, executive and judicial in relation to the State and its government are hereby declared to be, and to have been always, inherent in and possessed and retained by His Highness the Maharaja" (s.3, 1934 Regulation).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "nothing in the Instrument affects the continuance of the Maharajas sovereignty in and over his State" (cl.8, Instrument of Accession).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: A legislative body which is sovereign like an autocratic Ruler has power to do anything. (Re Delhi Laws Act).
key_quotes.speaker: court
